CONDITIONS FOR ENTRY TO BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA         (Article 2)    A foreigner who meets conditions for entry to BiH prescribed by Law on Aliens, may enter BiH if he/she at the BiH Border Crossing Points presents any of the following:    negative PCR test or rapid antigen test on SARS-CoV-2, not older than 48 hours if he/she comes from an European country, and if he/she comes from another country, not older than 72 hours until arrival at the border crossing point ofBosnia and Herzegovina,    certificate that a person has received the second dose of vaccine for COVID-19 before more than 14 days before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH or has received one dose before 14 days and more before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH, if it is a single dose vaccine,    certificate issued by doctor showing that he/she has recovered from COVID-19 in the previous period from 14 to 180 days until the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220113193549/http://www.granpol.gov.ba/Content/Read/76?title=Stranci&lang=en

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in BiH? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Private and public clinics throughout BiH perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test and current prices are roughly 100 convertible marks (km) for PCR and 40km for antigen.  Turnaround of results and availability of testing appointments vary based on the city yet clinics in most large cities have testing options daily and return results within 24 hours.  A list of clinics known to provide COVID-19 testing in BiH can be found on our website here  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) test symptomatic individuals regardless of nationality, free of charge. To arrange a test, contact your cantonâs health center for additional guidance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220114112145/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No evidence of contact tracing.

There are several measures travelers must take in order to enter the country. Vaccinated or recovered individuals must complete an entry form and present a negative test.  Not recovered and not vaccinated individuals must fill out the entry form, present a negative test, and turn in a second negative test between 4-7 days upon the arrival.     The government of Switzerland had a ban in place for "countries with a variant of concern", which meant that travelers from these destinations were prohibited from entering the country. However, as of now, there are no countries under this category.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20220105160134/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20220105160156/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/liste.html

This compensation applies to cases where employees are ordered to quarantine or to be isolated due to COVID-19. The amount of the support is set at 80% of eligible costs (compensation of wages paid to employees + the corresponding amount of statutory contributions), but a maximum of CZK 39,000 per employee and month. For employees, this means that they are in obstacles and receive a wage compensation of 60% of average earnings.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213105600/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/compensation/antivirus-plus-forced-limitations-service-operation-and-quarantine

Children in primary school will be sent home from Wednesday 15 December 2021 until (and including) Tuesday 4 January 2022. Pupils in boarding schools and independent vocational schools will be sent home from Sunday 19 December 2021 to (and including) Friday 7 January 2021.    While in school, however, Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately. Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to get tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 6 months. Two weekly tests are recommended in municipalities and parishes with high infection rates.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216151102/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen, OECD countries or  COVID-19 risk countries, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected must take a test before/within 24 hours after arrival.    2)  People coming in from areas with COVID-19 variants of concern within 10 days prior to the date of entering Denmark, must take a test within 24 hours of entry and immediately self-isolate for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival.       Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216152037/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

For people entering Denmark from an EU and / or Schengen country or COVID-19 risk country, there is no requirement for isolation after entry.    However, those entering from a COVID-19 high-risk country must self-isolate after entry, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected. The isolation is required for 10 days but the isolation may be ended after a negative PCR test taken at the earliest on the sixth day after the time of entry.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211231184528/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

Facial coverings are required in all public spaces in Spain: https://web.archive.org/web/20211229212801/https://www.thelocal.es/20211227/reminder-what-are-the-rules-and-exceptions-for-wearing-face-masks-outdoors-in-spain/  There are a two exceptions: face masks are not considered necessary outdoors  âduring individual sportsâ (for example, going for a jog or a cycle on your own) or âduring activities that are not sporting in nature, but are carried out in natural spacesâ, such as hanging out at the beach or hiking in the forest.     These exceptions are contingent on the 1.5 metre social distancing rules being maintained.    The face mask can also be removed outdoors in Spain by those travelling by boat, an exception that was included in the previous law. However, the new rules make masks mandatory below deck, even if social distancing is maintained.    Face masks will not be mandatory inside residences, centres for people with disabilities, or similar homes, provided that the vaccination rate is 80 percent or higher with the full schedule and booster doses.    External visitors and workers at these centers are still required to wear face masks.

Workplaces are open but the employers must evaluate the risks present in the working environment and enact measures to lower the risks: these measures can include requirement to wear a mask, testing, vaccination, re-organisation of work...    https://archive.ph/kFT6d

Workplaces are open but the employers must evaluate the risks present in the working environment and enact measures to lower the risks: these measures can include requirement to wear a mask, testing, vaccination, re-organisation of work, etc.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115161323/https://www.kriis.ee/en/work-life-and-being-away-work/employee/working-workplace

Since January 6th 2022, the country went into high risk level for covid-19 which means that distance working is highly recommended, in addition to the previous existing measures.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115161323/https://www.kriis.ee/en/work-life-and-being-away-work/employee/working-workplace  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115162302/https://kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/levels-risk  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115162911/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/risk-level-spread-coronavirus-became-very-high-again

At entertainment public establishments indoors it is obligatory for all persons from the age of 12 years and three months to present a valid COVID certificate.  Protective mask is obligatory for all person from the age of 12 or above    https://archive.ph/OjDhC#content_q10068237

Participants over the age of 12 must present a covid certificate, else they cannot participate.   Provided that the organiser ensures that the infection risk status of all the participants is checked, up to 1000 people may participate indoors and up to 2 000 people outdoors. Events must end before 11pm.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115155930/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions

In public spaces, gathering requires Covid certificates for all people over 12. The restriction does not apply to private events in private places.  Limitations to the number of participants: Up to 1000 people may participate in events and activities indoors and up to 2000 people outdoors.  Events must end no later than at 23.00 (the restriction is temporarily suspended between December 31, 2021 and the morning of January 2, 2022)    https://archive.ph/OjDhC#content_q10068237

Participants over the age of 12 must present a covid certificate. People without covid certificate cannot participate in public gatherings.   Provided that the organiser ensures that the infection risk status of all the participants is checked, up to 1000 people may participate indoors and up to 2 000 people outdoors.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115155930/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions
Masks must be worn in public transports for people over 12, but Covid certificates are not required.    https://archive.ph/ZspRN

Masks must be worn on public transport and hygiene measures are recommended  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115161435/https://www.kriis.ee/en/everyday-life-and-services/services/public-transport-and-getting-around
There is no stay at home requirement.    https://archive.ph/toR7y
No stay at home requirement   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115155930/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions

Depending on the country of origins, travelers may have to fill up a questionnaire, get tested or quarantine.   All travellers arriving from the risk countries of the Omicron strain or those who have been in the risk countries within the past 10 calendar days have to do a PCR test immediately after arriving in Estonia.     https://archive.ph/JVc1V

Depending of the country of origin, the list of requirement changes. Travelers might have to get tested, self-isolate and might need to present an imperial reason to be allowed to enter Estonia (work, studying, family reasons, or under a special permit).   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115162910/https://www.kriis.ee/en/travelling-crossing-state-border/travelling-estonia/who-subject-restrictions

In 2021, vaccination is free for everybody who lives in Estonia, over the age of 12.    https://archive.ph/7Zm9j

All residents of Estonia from the age of 12 are expected to get vaccinated for free against COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211128160602/https://www.kriis.ee/en/sickness-health-vaccinations/vaccines-and-vaccinations/covid-19-vaccines
Recommendations of sanitary measures are made for visitors of care homes. There is also a policy that the care homes have to follow in case of suspicion of infection.     https://archive.ph/I5YGi

Recommendations are made to protect elderly people.   Where possible, home-based services provided for the elderly by the local government of residence should be preferred to placement in a nursing home.  Residents of nursing homes should not be transferred between different homes.  Before meeting a person at risk, make sure you are safe from infection and ensure safety when meeting them: wear a mask, keep your distance, and clean your hands and surfaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115164650/https://www.kriis.ee/en/sickness-health-vaccinations/coronavirus-and-preventing-its-spread/prevention-coronavirus

The Nationwide Telework recommendation has now been reintroduced in areas currently experiencing increased levels of community transmission.   The recommendation is for all employees in the public sector to work remotely as extensively as possible if their duties so allow. The Government also recommends that private employers adopt similar extensive remote work practices, recognising, however, that workplaces will determine how to combine in-office and remote work in a way that ensures health security.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216145328/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/10623/government-recommends-remote-work-in-areas-in-the-community-transmission-phase-until-further-notice

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory    The Finnish Institute of Health and Welfare has restricted all travel to South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Lesotho, Eswatini (Swaziland), Malawi and Mozambique based on the new COVID-19 variant (B.1.1.529) from 27th November. Entry from these regions is also restricted and only allowed under certain circumstances.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212152923/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212153700/https://raja.fi/en/guidelines-for-border-traffic-during-pandemic

This test is mandatory    Archived: https://archive.vn/SVEDj

The requirements for entry into Finland include the following:   - a certificate of a full approved COVID-19 vaccination series, OR  - a certificate of having had the COVID-19 disease and one approved COVID-19 vaccine, OR  - an EU Digital COVID Certificate for a COVID-19 disease had less than six months ago, AND  - a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in Finland.    These requirements apply to those born in or before 2006. They however do not apply to citizens of Finland, those with permanent residence in Finland or persons travelling for essential reasons. Those who do not meet the requirement are required to have a mandatory covid test.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220106182331/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

These requirements apply to those born in or before 2006. They however do not apply to citizens of Finland, those with permanent residence in Finland or persons travelling for essential reasons. The amendment to the unemployment benefit legislation will be extended until 30 November 2021. Those laid off temporarily and the lay-off started on or after 16 March 2020, are eligible for an unemployment benefit even if they are studying. This is a temporary change that will be effective until 31 December 2021.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211017165013/https://www.kela.fi/web/en/unemployment-benefit-corona

A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with. The Finnish Institute of Health and Welfare recommends a third dose of coronavirus vaccine for    - persons with severe immunodeficiency and aged 12 or over  - persons who have been vaccinated with a short interval of less than 6 weeks and are aged 18 or over  all persons aged 60 and over  - persons living in institutions and care homes and aged 18 or over  - persons in medical high-risk groups 1 and 2 and aged 18 or over health care personnel who treat coronavirus patients, personnel of 24-hour care facilities and other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220113120359/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/vaccines-and-coronavirus/getting-vaccinated-against-covid-19-how-why-and-when-

No change to the policy implemented on 9 December: all primary schools are moved to Level 3/Orage level restrictions; facial coverings are required in playgrounds and contact sports are restricted. Masks continue to be required when inside for all staff and students aged 6 and over. Classes will be closed and learning moved online if there are more than 3 cases of COVID-19 in a particular class. In universities, barrier protection is required, masks are mandatory, and student who test positive and their contacts must self-isolate for 7 days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211226182600/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education
No change to policies implemented on 9 December. https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050328/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

Overall policy remains broadly similar to that introduced on 9 December 2021, but isolation and testing rules to be followed after the detection of a case of Covid-19 in a class have been modified from 3 January 2022 per https://web.archive.org/web/20220105124117/https://www.gouvernement.fr/les-regles-d-isolement-en-vigueur-en-milieu-scolaire-depuis-le-3-janvier     https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050328/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220114193949/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

Covid-19 protocols in schools have been simplified in order to allow education facilities to remain open. The following regulations, announced by the Prime Minister on 10 January, take effect as of 14 January:     - When a positive case is detected in a class, parents will no longer be asked to pick up their child immediately, they can wait for the end of the school day.  - When a positive case is detected in a classroom, case contacts aged under 12 years or those aged over 12 who have a complete vaccination schedule will be able to use 3 free self-tests provided by pharmacies, and will no longer have to perform a PCR or antigen test followed by two self-tests).  - Parents will no longer be asked to produce a certificate after each self-test: a single certificate will be requested. Children may not attend school if one of the self-tests is positive.     Additional measures were announced by the Minister of Education, Youth and Sports on 13 January, including:     - the distribution of 5 million FFP2 masks in establishments for staff who feel the need;  - the replenishment of the fund for the purchase of CO2 sensors as much as necessary, so that local authorities can request it even more massively.  - the recruitment of 3,300 more contract workers;  - the use of supplementary lists;  - the recruitment of educational assistants and support staff for school principals.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220114193949/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

Use of the Health Pass is required for access to many workplaces by both employees and customers. From 9 December, discotheques are to be closed until 6 January 2022, mand dancing in restaurants and bars is prohibited until the same date. The government recommends that 2 or 3 days per week of remote working are implemented in work environments where teleworking is possible, face-to-face meetings should be limited, and welcome and leaving ceremonies should be postponed.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211224033327/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20211222062141/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050347/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

From 3 January, the use of telework will be made compulsory for all employees for whom it is possible, at a minimum of three days per week and four days when possible. Discotheques and nightclubs are joined by standing concerts in being banned until at least 24 January, and those workplaces are thus closed. https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050347/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    National guidelines to ensure health and safety of employees were updated on 3 January, available at https://web.archive.org/web/20220103115103/https://www.gouvernement.fr/le-protocole-national-pour-assurer-la-sante-et-la-securite-des-salaries-en-entreprise-au-3-janvier
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220113111843/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Use of the Health Pass is required to access almost all public events. Prefects in all Departments are authorized to prohibit public events and gatherings, consumption of alcohol in public places, and are recommended to prohibit public events including fireworks and concerts where barrier methods cannot be implemented. https://web.archive.org/web/20211224033327/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050347/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

From 3 January, standing concerts are prohibited, joining the closure of discos and nightclubs until at least 24 January. Large scale events are limited to 2000 people indoors or 5000 people outdoors. https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050347/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
No change in policy. restrictions remain in place until at least 24 January - https://web.archive.org/web/20220113111843/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Use of the Health Pass is required for access to access many places or events where people gather, and these rules have applied since 21 July to access places of leisure and culture (including concert halls, amusement parks, concert halls, festivals, sports halls, games rooms, libraries and documentation centres, or cinemas), and have been extended since 9 August to cover:    - commercial catering activities (bars and restaurants, including on terraces), with the exception of collective catering or take-away of prepared meals, professional road and rail catering, room service in hotel restaurants and bars and non-commercial catering, including the free distribution of meals;  - trade fairs and exhibitions, and professional seminars;  - health, social and medico-social services and institutions, for persons accompanying or visiting persons accommodated in such services and establishments as well as for those who are accommodated there for scheduled care. This measure, which applies subject to emergency cases, does not have the effect of limiting access to care;  - long-distance travel by interregional public transport (domestic flights, TGV journeys, IntercitÃ©s and night trains, interregional coaches);  - department stores and shopping centers of more than 20,000mÂ²,by decision of the prefect of the department, when their characteristics and the seriousness of the risks of contamination justify it, under conditions guaranteeing access to people to essential goods and services as well as to the means of transport accessible within the walls of these stores and centers. Currently, shopping centers of more than 20,000 mÂ² located in departments under strong epidemic pressure are subject to the "health pass" after decision of the prefects concerned;  - ski lifts and Christmas markets (unless the prefect decides otherwise);  - access to tourist accommodation such as campsites or holiday clubs is subject to the "health pass", with a single control at the beginning of the stay;  - prefects have the possibility of making the "health pass" mandatory in places of gathering or on the occasion of events,such as markets for example.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226182727/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire    The government discourages private holiday gatherings, recommends avoiding kissing, and avoiding large gatherings of people (although there is no evidence of rules enfocing such behaviour) - https://web.archive.org/web/20211224033327/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

No major changes in policy, use of the Health Pass is required for access to access many places or events where people gather, and these rules have applied since 21 July 2021 to access places of leisure and culture (including concert halls, amusement parks, concert halls, festivals, sports halls, games rooms, libraries and documentation centres, or cinemas), and additional venues. aFrom 3 January large events (over 2000 people indoors or 5000 people outdoors) are banned until at least 23 January, and use of the Health Pass is required to access all other such events. Standing concerts are prohibited during this period. https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050347/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
No change in policy, https://web.archive.org/web/20220113111843/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Local transport remains open without restriction, use of the Health Pass is required for long-distance and inter-regional travel on buses, trains and airplanes - https://web.archive.org/web/20211226182727/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Local transport remains open without restriction, use of the Health Pass is required for long-distance and inter-regional travel on buses, trains and airplanes - https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050347/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

In addition to the requirement for use of the Health Pass to travel by long-distance public transport, from 3 January face coverings are required to be worn on all public transport, including local destinations. https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050347/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

No change in policy, use of the Health Pass continues to be mandatory for all long-distance or inter-regional public transport and face coverings are required on all forms of public transport - https://web.archive.org/web/20220113111843/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
No requirements to stay at home are in place - https://web.archive.org/web/20211224033327/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

There are no stay-at-home requirements in mainland France (though restrictions between the hours of 9pm and 5am are applied on the island of Reunion until at least 23 January) - https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050347/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
There are no stay-at-home requiremens in mainland France - https://web.archive.org/web/20220113111843/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
Use of the Health Pass is required for long-distance journeys on any form of public transport - https://web.archive.org/web/20211226182727/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Use the Health Pass remains mandatory to access long-distance public transport of all types - https://web.archive.org/web/20220113111843/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

From 00:00 on 18 December, new rules impact travel between the United Kingdom and France due to prevalence of the Omicron variant in the UK. All travellers twelve years of age or older, regardless of vaccination status, from the United Kingdom:    - are subject to the regime of compelling reasons,the list of which is specified in the certificate of travel and travel drawn up by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France and return to their residence in the United Kingdom: french people and their spouses and children;  - must present a negative PCR or antigen (TAG) test taken less than 24 hours before flight boarding;  - must register before departure on the eOS-COVID digital platform  (https://web.archive.org/web/20211202154207/https://passager.serveureos.org/);  - may be subject to an antigen test on arrival;  - will be subject to mandatory isolation for 10 days, supervised and controlled by the security forces. This isolation obligation may be lifted from 48 hours, subject to a negative PCR or antigen test.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20211218000501/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays-destination/royaume-uni/    Restrictions for travelers from other countries remain as per the update of 12 December - https://web.archive.org/web/20211217002052/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20211227022523/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 6 January, the classification of countries returns to the 3-stage system of Green/Orange/Red with the elimination of the temporary fourth "Scarlet Red" category. Countries of the travellers origin are categorised as follows:     "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, South Korea, The United Arab Emirates, Hong Kong, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories. Reinforced measures are in force for travel between France and the United Kingdom. The Travel Advice sheet for the United Kingdom should be consulted.    "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus with the presence of variants of concern is observed. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Botswana, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Georgia, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Moldova, Montenegro, Mozambique, Namibia, Nigeria, Pakistan, Russia, South Africa, Suriname, Tanzania, Turkey, Ukraine, the United States, Zambia and Zimbabwe.    All passengers from Red list countries must present negative results of a PCR or antigen test taken in the previous 48 hours at boarding and may be tested again on arrival. Unvaccinated passengers are subject to presentation of "compelling reasons" for travel, mandatory antigen testing on arrival, and must quarantine for 10 days under the control of security forces.     Passengers from Orange list countries must present negative results of a PCR or antigen test taken in the previous 48 hours at boarding. Vaccinated passengers are not subject to the "compelling reasons" regime, but unvaccinated people are and must commit to self-isolation lasting 7 days and undergo testing at the end of this period.     Although an Orange list country, additional regulations apply to all passengers aged 12 or over arriving from the United Kingdom:     - subject to the list of "compelling reasons"  - must present a negative PCR or antigenic (TAG) test taken less than 24 hours before the flight on boarding ;  - must register before departure on the eOS-COVID digital platform  ;  - may be tested antigen on arrival ;  - will be subject to mandatory isolation for 10 days,supervised and controlled by the security forces. This isolation obligation may be lifted from 48 hours, subject to being able to justify a negative test (PCR or TAG).    Specific guidance for UK passengers is available at https://web.archive.org/web/20220108054040/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays-destination/royaume-uni/    Passengers from Green List countries are divided into two groups:     1. Member States of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See and Switzerland - Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a test (PCR or antigenic) of less than 24 hours. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    2. Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Hong Kong, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, The United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu:  All travelers twelve years of age or older, regardless of their vaccination status,from these countries/territories must present for boarding, the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) carried out less than 48 hours before the flight.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050616/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

Vaccination is universally available to people aged over 12 years and two months. From 15 December, vaccination is available to children aged between 5 and 11 who are overweight or who have an underlying medical condition.     Vaccination booster is open to all people aged 18 and over from five months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    As of December 15, 2021, the rules relating to the "health pass" are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have made their recall, from the moment they are eligible (5 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 8 additional weeks maximum.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211207123504/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Vaccination is universally available to people aged over 12 years and two months. From 15 December, vaccination is available to children aged between 5 and 11 who are overweight or who have an underlying medical condition.     Vaccination booster is open to all people aged 18 and over from five months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    As of December 15, 2021, the rules relating to the "health pass" are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have made their recall, from the moment they are eligible (5 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 8 additional weeks maximum.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211224120928/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

From 22 December, vaccination is universally available to people aged over 5 years and older.    Vaccination booster is available to all people aged 18 and over from five months after the last injection and one month after the second injection, or five months after recovery from infection with Covid-19.    As of December 15, 2021, the rules relating to the "health pass" are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have received their booster vaccination, from the moment they are eligible (5 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 8 additional weeks maximum.    People aged 80 and over with mobility issues are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211224120928/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211228110012/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

In addition to the protections afforded to the general population, vaccination is mandatory for all people in contact with frail and elderly people, including caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers.     From December 15, rules for the Health Pass have changed for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have received a booster vaccine, from the moment they are eligible (i.e. 6 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 4 additional weeks maximum. Beyond this time, their QR code will be deactivated automatically.     For people aged over 80 years of age who have mobility issues and wish to benefit from a vaccination at home can access a special toll-free number to put them in touch with services likely to offer them a vaccination at home.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211215185817/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

The UK is removing all countries from its red travel list, just weeks after reactivating the list in response to the new Omicron variant.    As of tomorrow, 15 December, people arriving from 11 African countries will no longer need to stay in one of the government-run quarantine hotels.    People currently in a UK quarantine hotel will also be allowed to leave early, as long as they do not test positive for COVID-19.    However all current testing requirements will remain in place, Transport Secretary Grant Shapps confirmed on Twitter this afternoon.    he UK recently updated its travel rules, stipulating that all arrivals must now show a negative pre-departure PCR or lateral flow test that was taken within 48 hours of arriving.    This is in addition to a day 2 PCR test, which both UK citizens and visitors must await the results of in isolation. The rules vary for unvaccinated travellers.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211215095343/https://www.euronews.com/travel/2021/12/14/uk-travel-all-countries-removed-from-the-uk-s-red-quarantine-list

On December 1, cinema and theater attendances will grow from 30% to 50%. On December 1, restrictions on restaurant opening hours will be lifted. The ban on concerts and festivals is removed so long as applicable regulations are observed. Restriction remains valid on holding the wide-scale entertainment and such social events, as wedding parties, banquets, jubilees of various types and similar. Eateries and ritual venues of miscellaneous types will be sanctioned with 10 000 GEL for hosting such events but will be sealed if found in breach of the regulation for the second time.   Also, camping of any type is banned, regardless of the organizational form or venue.   Any type of entertainment activities, arts and culture events (except for stage performances and cinema), festivals are going to be fully banned. The referred restriction does not apply to concerts to be held at the premises of hotels. As for sports tournaments of various types, they may be held without spectators. Nevertheless, every participant should be vaccinated (14 days should be lapsed from the second dose) or have a PCR test result obtained in the past 72 hours or a negative result of an antigen test obtained in the past 24 hours.  Amendments have been made to Government Resolution N322 dated May 23, 2020 on the Adoption of the Rules of Isolation and Quarantine, according to which delegates will be allowed to attend conferences, trainings and seminars from July 19, 2021 only with a negative PCR test taken 72 hours prior or express antigen test taken 24 hours prior to the event and/or without the latter on the 14th day from full vaccination.   Source: https://archive.vn/qcOkW

As of November 28, 2021, any person who has a travel history to the countries listed below during last 14 days is subject to a 14-day mandatory quarantine in a Georgian government facility upon entry into Georgia.  After completing the 14-day quarantine, the traveler must undergo a PCR test.  Foreign citizens are personally responsible for the cost of quarantine and PCR testing.  Republic of South Africa  Republic of Botswana  Republic of Zimbabwe  Republic of Namibia  Kingdom of Lesotho  Kingdom of Eswatini (Swaziland)  Republic of Mozambique  Republic of Malawi  Source: https://archive.vn/EohxU.

Schools will reopen on Jan. 10 with stricter testing protocols as ânothing can replace live teaching for the psycho-emotional development of our children,â Education Minister Niki Kerameus said Tuesday.    https://web.archive.org/web/%2A/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-01-04/greece-to-reopen-schools-as-planned-on-monday-amid-record-cases

Indoor entertainment venues, restaurants, bars and cafes will only be accessible to vaccinated or recently recovered customers, with verification checks conducted at entrances through an app that scans COVID-19 certificates.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211105110420/https://apnews.com/article/europe-business-health-greece-coronavirus-pandemic-9656434341e8db7aa36fd73a2cbbb50c

Greece reintroduced measures aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus pandemic amid concern that rising cases will pile pressure on the nationâs health care system.    As much as 50% of all private and public-sector employees will have to work from home between Jan. 3 and Jan. 16, Health Minister Athanasios Plevris said Monday. The government also ordered restaurants, bars, cafes and night clubs to close at midnight.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161816/https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=ea7e0e9d-7230-11ec-a53d-5a7175777570&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAyMS0xMi0yNy9ncmVlY2UtcmVpbnN0YXRlcy13b3JrLWZyb20taG9tZS1tYW5kYXRlLW5pZ2h0LWxpZmUtY3VyYnM=

no policy change     At level 4 (red) of the Epidemiology Charter country incorporated the Regional Units Kavala, Imathia, Pieria and Pella , while extending a special, local, measures in Regional Units Haryana and Argolis , after re-evaluation of epidemiological data the Committee of Infectious Diseases and the National Committee for the Protection of Public Health against the Covid-19 coronavirus in the context of the epidemiological surveillance of the country by Regional Unit and Municipality on a weekly basis.    At the same time, level 3 (orange) includes the Regional Units of Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Heraklion , as well as the Municipality of Ikaria .    It is reminded that the measures in force are the following:    Traffic ban from 01:00 in the evening until 06:00 in the morning, with the exception of work and serious health reasons.  Prohibition of music around the clock in stores of health interest and entertainment.  The measures are valid from tomorrow, Friday 17 September at 06.00 until Friday 24 September at 6:00 .    It is also reminded that in these areas, as well as in the whole territory, it is forbidden to hold any form of events in exchange for any form of exchange, with the physical presence of a crowd of more than twenty (20) people in a private, non-professional space . The administrative fine in case of violation amounts from 50,000 to 200,000 euros for the lessee or concessionaire of the private, non-professional space, in which the said event took place or takes place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210919221253/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/simantika-themata/sto-epipedo-4-toy-epidimiologikoy-harti-tis-horas-kavala-imathia-pieria-kai-pella  Enter new data here for Greece. no policy change     Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210802101710/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

All those travelling to Greece (aged 5 or above) must show proof of a professionally administered negative rapid COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before arrival or proof of a professionally administered negative PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival.     The measure affects all arrivals, regardless of vaccination status or country of departure. The only exception is for arrivals who have spent less than 48 hours in a country prior to arriving in Greece.                                              Random antigen testing on arrival applies to every arrival to Greece, regardless of the certificate in their possession. If you are selected, please keep in mind that the screening is mandatory and in case of refusal, authorities reserve the right to refuse entry into the country.    If you are selected for a test and test positive, you will be subject to mandatory quarantine, for which you may be required by the Greek authorities to move to a designated quarantine facility.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161137/https://www.dfa.ie/travel/travel-advice/a-z-list-of-countries/greece/

Guidelines for primary schools, day care institutions and recreational activities:  -In the case of infection at schools and institutions etc., it will most often be other contacts that are of concern.  -Children, who are other contacts to an infected person (child or employee) in a day-care nursery etc., in school (including boarding schools and private schools) or in connection with recreational activities, must follow the recommendations for other contacts. Learn more in the section If you have been together with an infected person/been exposed to infection but are not a close contact.  -However, roommates at boarding schools etc., must follow the guidelines for close contacts.  *updated guidelines since 12 Jan 2022  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117002207/https://corona.nun.gl/en/at-the-workplace/guidelines-for-primary-schools-day-care-and-after-school-activities/

Please find information about any current local restrictions here. Please note that the page might be in Danish.  -Workplaces, educational institutions, etc. should clearly mark entrances with signs stating that access is prohibited for persons with COVID-19 symptoms and should have clear procedures in place for the handling of personnel, students, visitors etc. with COVID-19 symptoms, including how working at home/studying at home can be organised.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212154457/https://corona.nun.gl/en/at-the-workplace/suliffeqarfimmi-malittarisassat-2-3/

In Greenland, there is a requirement for vaccination against COVID-19 or a negative PCR test, which is a maximum of 48 hours old, for people who want to stay in premises and associated areas with public access.  -The requirement applies to citizens over 12 years of age.  -You must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have a negative test  -You are only allowed access to the following places if you are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have a negative PCR test that is a maximum of 48 hours old:  1) Restaurants, cafes, pubs, discos and similar establishments and their adjoining outdoor areas.  2) Cultural institutions, including culture centres, cinemas, museums, exhibition halls, etc.  3) Community centres and similar establishments.  4) Libraries.  5) Indoor and outdoor sports facilities, including sports colleges and sports halls, swimming pools, gyms, football pitches, etc.  6) Hairdressers, massage parlours, beauty clinics and similar establishments.    When are you fully vaccinated?  -People who have completed a full vaccination programme, for example two doses of Pfizer or Moderna vaccine or one dose of Johnson&Johnson vaccine, are considered fully vaccinated. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.  -If you have previously been infected with COVID-19 and can present documentation of a positive PCR test result which is between 14 days and 12 weeks old, you are covered by the same rules as if you were fully vaccinated.  *updated definition of being fully vaccinated  https://web.archive.org/web/20211228235327/https://corona.nun.gl/en/corona-passport-digital-eu-covid-certificate/vaccination-as-a-requirement-for-access/

This also applies if you have a stopover in Greenland, e.g. in Kangerlussuaq, before you travel out of the country.  -The owner of the means of transportation is responsible for ensuring that all travellers obey the rules.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211229000442/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/domestic-travel-in-greenland/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or a resident of Greenland or you are relocating to Greenland.    -In regard to entering Greenland, you are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -You must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test from a Nordic country (Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Iceland, Faroe Islands), UK, Liechtenstein, Switzerland, or a country in EU that is maximum 48 hours old from the time of departure and have valid documentation showing this.  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. This rule applies to everyone at 12 years old or older.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211220215011/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Face masks can be used as a supplement for preventing the spread of infection in situations where it is difficult to keep to distance. It is important that you continue to follow the advice relating to keeping a distance and good hygiene even when you wear a face mask.    In Greenland, you must wear a face mask in the following situations:  -When you are in premises with public access in cities and settlements with a current spread of infection with COVID-19. Find the list of cities and settlements with current spread of infection in Area restrictions.  -All individuals aged 12 years or older on domestic or international flights (face masks must be worn to the quarantine location/end destination).  -If you have been infected or risk of being infected with COVID-19 and in exceptional circumstances must move outside, e.g. because you need to get tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206143427/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/use-of-face-masks-and-visors/

In order to adapt as much as possible to the new conditions, employers are advised to organize, wherever possible, work from home or work in shifts, in order to avoid interference by workers. For the protection of one's own, but also the health of others, it is recommended that all business trips be postponed and that meetings be held online. Jobs related to the health care system also have specially prescribed measures that employees must adhere to so that the system itself is not overloaded. All recommendations for employees and employers in trade, catering facilities, measures for drivers in road freight transport or employees in the state administration, can be found here.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112163018/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-poslu/46

Fines for Non-Compliance:  Health Inspectors of the Croatian State Inspectorate are monitoring and enforcing individual orders to self-isolate. They are authorized to fine any individual violating this order with fines ranging from 8000 HRK for the first violation to 30,000 HRK, 60,000 HRK and 120,000 HRK for repeat offenders. Persons violating health inspector orders may also be subject to criminal charges.  People caught not wearing a mask (or improperly wearing a mask) in mask-designated areas will be fined 500 HRK, but they will be eligible to pay half that amount (250 HRK) if they agree to put on a mask immediately.  Legal entities will be fined 10,000-40,000 HRK if they do not respect the epidemiological measures related to public gatherings.  Businesses will be fined 5,000-10,000 HRK for not implementing epidemiological measures.  Passengers in transit (individuals in transit have 12 hours to exit the country, and they must show that they can enter or transit through the neighboring country). Fines in violation of this provision range from 5,000 to 10,000 HRK.    Restrictions for Individuals and Businesses  Businesses and individuals may be restricted due to the epidemiological measures based on your location in Croatia. Most notable epidemiological restrictions may include a requirement to wear a mask indoors unless seated in a restaurant or coffee shop. Venues hosting larger audiences may require visitors to present a negative COVID-19 test or record of vaccination. Some venues like night clubs or concert halls offer onsite rapid testing services for a fee. Wedding parties of up to 120 guests are permitted with a mandate that all guests, staff, and entertainers must have been vaccinated or recovered from COVID-19 or have a negative viral test.    Individual counties and cities may have additional measures. Please visit?the?Croatian Governmentâs COVID-19 website?for additional information.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211206183854/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

the Headquarters passed a new Decision which regulates, ie restricts gatherings, which will take effect tomorrow , and the most important changes are:    It is forbidden to hold all public events and gatherings indoors where more than 50 people are present in one place, unless it is a public event or gathering attended only by persons with EU digital COVID certificate , and the same is the responsibility of the civil headquarters. protection of local self-government units gave consent. (so far it referred to more than 100)  Measures are being tightened to hold all public events and gatherings indoors with more than 50 people, where, with the participation of the EU digital COVID certificate, it will be mandatory to use a medical mask or face mask and maintain the necessary physical distance . (so far this has not been mandatory for gatherings with the EU digital COVID certificate).  The measure of banning all public events and outdoor gatherings attended by more than 100 people in one place is still valid, unless it is a public event or gathering attended only by persons with an EU digital COVID certificate . The strict recorded rules (in place as of 1st December) state: From December 1, travelers arriving from South Africa, Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Zimbabwe, Namibia and Hong Kong, or those who have visited any of these destinations in the past 14 days, are not permitted to enter Croatia due to the discovery of the Omicron variant.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211220233356/https://edition.cnn.com/travel/article/croatia-travel-covid-19/index.html

The Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia issued a Decision temporarily prohibiting and restricting the crossing of persons across all border crossing points of the Republic of Croatia (NN 3/21). However, in accordance with the guidelines of the competent authorities, exceptions have been made as follows.    Officially the border is closed while there are existing exceptions which allow people to enter the country    https://www.koronavirus.hr/o-covidu/736

Pursuant to the Decision passengers (regardless of their citizenship) who arrive from the Republic of South Africa, Botswana, the Kingdom of Eswatini, Lesotho, Namibia, Zimbabwe and Republic of Mozambique or who stayed in those countries in the last 14 days are not allowed to enter the Republic of Croatia.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220109223019/https://mup.gov.hr/uzg-covid/english/286212

On Wednesday, December 15, 2021, the Croatian Parliament amended the Law on the Protection of the Population from Infectious Diseases. It introduces fines of 30 to 50 thousand kuna for responsible persons who do not respect the obligation to present covid certificates in public law bodies.    On the same day, the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia made seven new decisions that are valid from 16 December to 31 December this year, when they will be considered again. The Headquarters extended the Decision on the introduction of a special security measure in the social welfare sector.    The decision implies âmandatory testing of all employees for the SARS-CoV-2 virus in the social welfare activity, ie in social welfare institutions, associations, religious communities, other legal entities, craftsmen and natural persons who perform social welfare as a professional activity and the Center for Social Welfare. special guardianship, who come to work at least twice in seven days. ". Exceptionally, testing is not mandatory for employees who "qualify for vaccination or recovery from COVID-19 unless they have signs of respiratory infection, other symptoms, or signs of COVID-19 infectious disease."    Recall, from mid-November this year, covid-certificates are mandatory for all employees of public and state services, as well as users of their services.    The same decision applies to all parties who come there, all service providers who provide services in those premises or other persons who come there on any grounds. Those who refuse to present a certificate cannot enter the premises.    The EU digital covid-certification system has been developed at the level of the European Union, and 42 countries are participating in it.    https://www.koronavirus.hr/produzuje-se-vecina-covid-mjera-uvedene-velike-kazne-za-nepostivanje-predocenja-covid-potvrda/1002
No evidence of continued income support.
No change in prior policy

There are various restrictions based on the type of events, they can freely take place up to a certain number of people, more people can be allowed only if show proof of vaccination. Family gatherings and other private events (100 people), weddings (400 people), sport, cultural, music and dance events (only vaccinated), village festivals (1500 people). Other events only up to 500 people, with vaccine cards also more participants. While the lowest threshold is 100, most restrictions are above that threshold.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220111214419/https://visithungary.com/articles/general-regulations
Public transport only requires masks.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220111214419/https://visithungary.com/articles/general-regulations

Using vaccines: Pfizer- BioNTech, Moderna, Sputnik, AstraZeneca, Sinopharm and Janssen. Hungary started vaccinating children above 5 years from December 14. The campaign for the booster is intensive (children above 12 can already receive the booster). 7/1/22  The social distance between individuals is increased to 2 metres.  The use of face masks is compulsory in places where the 2-m social distance cannot be guaranteed; these include shops.  At events: A maximum of 20 persons may occupy each separate area, sitting in numbered seats allocated to them by name.  Sports that do not involve physical contact, in which it is possible to observe the 2-m social distance and a maximum of 20 participants in each separate area, are permitted, both indoors and out of doors.  Notwithstanding the 2-metre social distance requirement, physical contact is permitted between sportsmen at practices and in competitions held by the National Olympic and Sports Association of Iceland (ÃSÃ), but they are to observe the 2-m social distance rule in changing rooms and other parts of the premises when not taking part in competitions or practices. Notwithstanding the general maximum of 20 persons, up to 50 persons may gather at practices and competitions organised by the Association.    No spectators are permitted at sporting events, either indoors or out of doors.  Sports and fitness activities: Subject to certain conditions, sports and fitness activities may be organised and pursued providing that these are structured group sessions in which all participants are registered, the maximum size of each group being 20 persons. In these cases, the 2-metre social distance rule shall be observed, participants may not exchange equipment during the session and all equipment shall be disinfected between sessions. Shared use of equipment that is fixed to the floor, ceiling or wall, or of large items of equipment (e.g. in fitness and body-building centres) is prohibited.    https://archive.fo/7O6wC

11/01/22  Current restrictions on school activities  The regulation issued by the Minister of Health on the restriction of school activities due to stricter infection prevention measures is effective until 2 February 2022.    Preschools and day-care parents  Maximum number of employees in each area: 20.  Minimum distance between employees: 2 metres.  Use of masks by employees: Where a 2-metre distance limit between employees is not possible. There is no mask obligation in communication with preschool children.  Transfer of employees between groups: Allowed.  Maximum number of children in each area: 50.  Minimum distance between children: None.  Use of face masks by children: None.  Outside area: no limits to the number of people.    Events related to the work or social activities of preschools, such as plays and concerts, may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.      Primary schools and after-school activities  Grades 1 to 10    Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between employees: 2 metres.  Use of masks by employees: Where a 2-metre distance limit between employees and towards students is not possible.  Transfer of employees and students between groups: Allowed.  Maximum number of children in each area: 50.  Minimum distance between children: 1 metre in classrooms.  Use of face masks by children: None.  Physical education and school swimming lessons: Allowed.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.  Outdoor area: No restrictions, but efforts should be made to limit the number of students in each outdoor area unless it impedes outdoor activities.    The restrictions on the number of people do not apply on the school bus.    Events related to the work or social activities of primary schools, such as lectures, reading competitions, etc., may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.    After-school activities  The same restrictions apply as apply to preschools and primary schools. One individual is allowed to accompany a child of a preschool age in after-school activities.    Events related to the work or social activities of primary schools, such as plays and concerts, lectures, reading competitions, etc., may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.    Mixing between groups: Allowed.    Music schools  All music lessons for children at a preschool and primary school age is permitted with the same restrictions as apply to their school activities.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between individuals: 2 metres.  Use of face masks: Students born in 2005 and earlier, as well as employees, should wear masks if social distancing rules cannot be followed, if possible.  Transfer of employees between areas: Allowed.  Maximum number of students in an area: 50.  Studentsâ social distancing rules: Follow the rules for each school level.    Events related to the work or social activities of music schools, such as concerts, may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.    Upper secondary schools  Maximum number of employees and students in an area: 50.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between individuals: 2 metres.  Use of face masks: Where a 2-metre distance is not possible.  In classrooms, it is permitted to have a distance of 1 metre between students, but then the use of a face mask is required.  Transfer of employees and students between groups: Allowed.  Physical education: Allowed with the same restrictions as other teaching measures.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.    In situations where it is not possible to enforce social distancing, such as in practical teaching, art teaching and teaching students in vocational training, students and teachers must wear a face mask.  Students may stay in a dormitory.  Events not related to teaching or education are not to be conducted on the school premises.  Events related to work or social activities in upper secondary school are subject to the provisions on performing arts in the regulation on the restrictions on gatherings due to a pandemic.    Universities  Maximum number of employees and students per room: 50.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between individuals: 2 metres.  Use of face masks: Where a 2-metre distance is not possible.  In classrooms, it is permitted to have a distance of 1 metre between students, but then the use of a mask is required.  Transfer between groups: Allowed.  Physical education: Allowed with the same restrictions as other teaching measures.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.  In situations where it is not possible to enforce social distancing, such as in practical teaching, art teaching and clinical studies, school work is permitted as long as infection prevention measures are followed and on the condition that students and teachers wear a face mask.    Other events not related to teaching or education are not to be conducted on the school premises.  This provision does not prevent students from staying in dormitories.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116174134/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

Use of masks by employees: Where a 2-metre distance limit between employees and towards students is not possible.  Transfer of employees and students between groups: Allowed.  Maximum number of children in each area: 50.  Minimum distance between children: 1 metre in classrooms.  Use of face masks by children: None.  Physical education and school swimming lessons: Allowed.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.  Outdoor area: No restrictions, but efforts should be made to limit the number of students in each outdoor area unless it impedes outdoor activities.    The restrictions on the number of people do not apply on the school bus.    Events related to the work or social activities of primary schools, such as lectures, reading competitions, etc., may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.    After-school activities  The same restrictions apply as apply to preschools and primary schools. One individual is allowed to accompany a child of a preschool age in after-school activities.    Events related to the work or social activities of primary schools, such as plays and concerts, lectures, reading competitions, etc., may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.    Mixing between groups: Allowed.    Music schools  All music lessons for children at a preschool and primary school age is permitted with the same restrictions as apply to their school activities.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between individuals: 2 metres.  Use of face masks: Students born in 2005 and earlier, as well as employees, should wear masks if social distancing rules cannot be followed, if possible.  Transfer of employees between areas: Allowed.  Maximum number of students in an area: 50.  Studentsâ social distancing rules: Follow the rules for each school level.    Events related to the work or social activities of music schools, such as concerts, may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.    Upper secondary schools  Maximum number of employees and students in an area: 50.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between individuals: 2 metres.  Use of face masks: Where a 2-metre distance is not possible.  In classrooms, it is permitted to have a distance of 1 metre between students, but then the use of a face mask is required.  Transfer of employees and students between groups: Allowed.  Physical education: Allowed with the same restrictions as other teaching measures.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.    In situations where it is not possible to enforce social distancing, such as in practical teaching, art teaching and teaching students in vocational training, students and teachers must wear a face mask.  Students may stay in a dormitory.  Events not related to teaching or education are not to be conducted on the school premises.  Events related to work or social activities in upper secondary school are subject to the provisions on performing arts in the regulation on the restrictions on gatherings due to a pandemic.    Universities  Maximum number of employees and students per room: 50.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between individuals: 2 metres.  Use of face masks: Where a 2-metre distance is not possible.  In classrooms, it is permitted to have a distance of 1 metre between students, but then the use of a mask is required.  Transfer between groups: Allowed.  Physical education: Allowed with the same restrictions as other teaching measures.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.  In situations where it is not possible to enforce social distancing, such as in practical teaching, art teaching and clinical studies, school work is permitted as long as infection prevention measures are followed and on the condition that students and teachers wear a face mask.    Other events not related to teaching or education are not to be conducted on the school premises.  This provision does not prevent students from staying in dormitories.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116174134/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions
No changes    https://web.archive.org/web/20220102151228/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/workplaces

?10/1/2022  Managers are responsible for informing their employees of the workplaceâs response plan and what rules apply to its operation while the COVID-19 precautionary measures remain in effect. The need for meetings must be assessed, particularly if there are many attendees. Such meetings should preferably be held using teleconferencing equipment whenever possible. This also applies to meetings within the company if possible. Care must be taken as regards employee travel overseas. Then ecessity of travel must be assessed each time, and employees should avoid such travel unless it is unavoidable.    It is important that managers encourage their employees to take care of their health and to stay at home if they experience any illness. Employees with underlying illnesses are particularly at risk from the virus and should, therefore, consult with their superior as to the possibility of working from home as much as possible if that is an option.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110105656/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/workplaces

Up to 50 people may attend an event if the following criteria is met:  1) All guests are seated and not facing each other  2) 1 meter social distancing between guests  3) All attendees were a mask.  4) Alcoholic beverages are not sold before, during or after event.  5) Guests are asked to remain seated even if an interval is necessary, if at all possible.  Up to 200 people may attend an event if the criteria above is met and all attendees, born 2015 and earlier present a certificate for:  a) a negative rapid antigen test known to detect omicron, taken no longer than 48 hours in advance, from a certified test center. Note that self-tests are not accepted.  b) or a recent COVID-19 infection (older than 14 days but not older than 180 days).  All guests are seated and not facing each other  1 meter social distancing between guests  All attendees were a mask.  Alcoholic beverages are not sold before, during or after event.  Guests are asked to remain seated even if an interval is necessary, if at all possible.    https://archive.ph/Zcxrx

?10/1/2022  People living in Iceland are strongly advised against unnecessary travel to risk areas due to COVID-19, except being fully vaccinated. Special rules apply when travelling to Iceland. A final decision on entry is in all cases made at the border.    Rules at the border  With vaccination certificate or a certificate of previous infection  Travelers without a vaccination certificate or a certificate of previous infection  Transit passengers    Trips abroad  Residents of Iceland are advised not to travel to risk areas without vaccination.
