Three types of COVID-tests are in use. PCR-tests are used by the health care system to test people with COVID-19 symptoms, and when people might be infected. Rapid antigen tests are also used in the health care system and by certified test centers, both before events, but also at the beginning and end of special precaution. Self-tests people can buy in stores are not deemed reliable. A negative result from a self-test does not grant access to events with up to 500 people. A postitive result should always be confirmed with a PCR test.  https://archive.ph/D2RpU

10/1/2022  Three types of COVID-tests are in use. PCR-tests are used by the health care system to test people with COVID-19 symptoms, and when people might be infected.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211219162808/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/testing-due-to-symptoms    Additional information  Announcements  Isolation ends  January 8, 2022  Due to the heavy workloads at LandspÃ­tali's Covid outpatient ward and the Civil Protection's Tracing Team, the Chief Epidemiologist has announced that those who have already completed seven days of isolation, do not experience any symptoms of COVID-19 and have not been able to contact the covid outpatient ward, can and may discharge themselves.    There is no need to try to contact the outpatient ward. Only those who are experiencing worsening symptoms need to contact the ward.    As before, day zero is the day an individual takes a PCR test, which is positive. Neither a positive at-home test nor a rapid antigen test can be used as a benchmark for day zero.    As previously stated, the amended rules came into force yesterday, regarding quarantine for those who have received a booster dose and are exposed to COVID-19. For emphasis, this applies to everyone who is in quarantine, including those who are in the same place as an infected individual.    It is important to keep in mind that those who do not have to meet the previous conditions of quarantine must nevertheless meet certain conditions (see also below) and take a PCR test on the fifth day from the date of exposure.  We must continue to look after vulnerable groups in society and pursue individual infection control measures as never before.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110112145/https://www.covid.is/announcements

16/01/22  Three types of COVID-tests are in use. PCR-tests are used by the health care system to test people with COVID-19 symptoms, and when people might be infected. Rapid antigen tests are also used in the health care system and by certified test centers, both before events, but also at the beginning and end of special precaution. Self-tests people can buy in stores are not deemed reliable. A postitive result should always be confirmed with a PCR test.    Information on centres for COVID-19 PCR or rapid antigen tests  PCR-test - Symptom testing:  If you have symptoms or suspect you have an infection, you should be tested even if you have been vaccinated.  Stay at home and register immediately for testing on My Page at Heilsuvera. If you do not have an electronic ID, you can contact, by telephone, your local healthcare centre, LÃ¦knavaktin 1700 (the on-call medical hotline) or the Heilsuvera online chat. If you have not been in contact with someone infected you are not obliged to islolate until a negative test result is obtained. However it is important to be mindful of social distancing and handwashing and to use a mask if it is nessessary to be around others. You should not, under any circumstances, visit your healthcare centre, the LSH Emergency Unit or LÃ¦knavaktin if you have symptoms, without calling first and receiving advice.  PCR-tests are also used for shortened quarantine. See below.  The symptoms may seem minor but it is still important to be tested, no matter how small they seem.  Symptom testing is always free of charge, for tourists as well.  Rapid antigen test - testing for asymptomatic people  Rapid antigen tests are used to screen for COVID-19 virus with asymptomatic people. If you suspect you have an infection, you should have a PCR-test.  Self-tests  Self-tests are not deemed reliable. If you test positive on a self-test, you should go for a PCR test (free) immediatly and follow the rules on isolation until your results are ready.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220116183316/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/testing-due-to-symptoms
There is no information available on contact tracing

10/1/2022  You quarantine if:  You've been in a relationship with someone who turned out to be infected.  You are traveling abroad and do not have a vaccination certificate or previous COVID-19 infection.  You do not quarantine if:  You've been with someone who was later quarantined.  Your neighbor is infected (for example, in the same stairwell), unless you have been in a lot of contact.  Quarantine ends:  Quarantine can be shortened to 5 days if you go for sampling, otherwise quarantine is 14 days.  You will automatically receive a barcode for the sampling, you do not need to register specifically for it.  A quarantine that takes place in a home where someone is in isolation ends with a negative result from sampling after the isolation has been lifted. Households can then expect a quarantine day longer than isolation lasts. In order to fulfill the conditions for shortening the quarantine to 5 days, there must be a complete separation between the person in isolation and the person in the quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206184014/https://www.covid.is/undirflokkar/sottkvi

10/1/2022  Face masks  Face masks must be worn wherever the 2 metre social distancing rule cannot be observed between people who are unrelated.    Mask obligation does not apply to children born 2016 or later.  Face masks must be worn in stores and shopping centers.  Face masks must be used where it is not possible to ensure 2 metre of social distancing, such as in healthcare services, museums, domestic flights and ferries, public transport, taxis and coaches, in practical driving lessons and flight training, hairdressers, beauty salons, massage parlours, tattoo parlours, dog grooming salons, tanning salons and other similar activities. Face mask needs to cover both nose and mouth.    Those who do not have the understanding or maturity to use a face mask correctly or are unable to do so for other reasons, such as health reasons, do not have to wear a mask.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110110201/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

no changes in policy, green passes are still required for university students.    Starting September 1st green passes are required for School Personnel only. All students are exempted from this requirement for the time being until and including high school. University students though need to have green passes in order to access the facilities of their university. Universities hence are virtually closed for students without a green pass.    Starting Dec 6th a vaccine mandate is in place for all school personnel.   University students still need to hold a green pass to attend lessons in presence.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211210170128/https://www.wired.it/article/green-pass-scuola-universita-regole-vaccino-mezzi/

Super Green Pass (green pass only for the vaccinated or recovered from covid, tests are not part of such green pass) will not be required in most workplaces. Vaccine mandates are only in place for healthcare workers, LTCF , law enforcement and school personnel. Although the methodology to perform contact tracing has not changed (all close contacts need to be tested or self-quarantine if they don't want to be tested), since the end of December contact tracing has been struggling to trace all close contacts of positives. With very high positive numbers (around 219000 on January 6th) and over a million tests performed most days, the tracing methodology is struggling to function and test everyone: long queues have been forming to get tested as well as long delays to get the results.  It seems the tracing methodology is still comprehensive though so marking as such  https://web.archive.org/web/20211228213909/https://gazzettadelsud.it/articoli/cronaca/2021/12/28/covid-tracciamento-dei-contatti-e-file-per-i-tamponi-il-sistema-e-andato-in-tilt-0f087917-40ef-4c83-8530-840469ae6f48/   https://web.archive.org/web/20220106175030/https://www.offida.info/covid-record-di-contagi-in-italia-e-nelle-marche/

Is public transportation operating?  Yes  The Chief Sanitary Doctor of Kazakhstan has mandated that masks be worn nationwide in public settings, including both indoor and outdoor spaces and on public transportation.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220108012336/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  The city of Nur-Sultan and the regions of Akmola, Karaganda, Kostanay, and Pavlodar are classified as yellow zones. Some additional measures are typically enforced in yellow zones:  Public transport operates from 06:00-23:00 Monday-Saturday and is suspended on Sundays.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20211220054019/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/551076/kazakhstan-authorities-announce-tightening-of-international-entry-restrictions-due-to-omicron-covid-19-variant-from-dec-3-update-50
No changes found

Nationwide, authorities require residents to obtain a government-provided QR code via the Ashyq mobile application to visit government offices and certain public spaces, including leisure facilities, cultural venues, and entertainment establishments. Ashyq codes are also required to gain entry to international airports in Almaty and Nur-Sultan. Residents will have their app scanned at each establishment; each QR code scan will reveal a resident's color-coded risk rating:    Red - movement restricted to self-isolation regime    Yellow - movement partially restricted; essential trips to nearest pharmacy and grocery store permitted    Blue - no specific restrictions    Green - no specific restrictions, and the user has a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test.    Authorities could reimpose, extend, further ease, or otherwise amend any restrictions with little-to-no notice depending on disease activity over the coming weeks.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20211220054019/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/551076/kazakhstan-authorities-announce-tightening-of-international-entry-restrictions-due-to-omicron-covid-19-variant-from-dec-3-update-50

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  Yes, in some cases.  As of May 11, 2021, the Government of Kazakhstan began prohibiting people who accompany departing travelers or meet arriving passengers from entering airports and rail stations in regions in high risk âRed Zones.â An exception exists for airports and rail stations participating in the âAshyqâ application system (please see further information on âAshyqâ in the Quarantine Information paragraph below).  Kazakhstanâs regions are empowered to take additional measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 as necessary, including erecting checkpoints to limit travel in and out of cities and oblasts.  Before pursuing domestic travel in Kazakhstan, we urge you to research whether checkpoints might be in place that could restrict your ability to travel.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220108012336/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Kazakhstan?  Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within one calendar day?  Yes  https://web.archive.org/web/20211120144442/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No manual contact tracing.     However the Ashyq app is available:    "The mobile application "Ashyq" enables through the use of a QR code and integration with the general database of the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Kazakhstan, to determine the status of a visitor: whether he is currently a carrier of the virus or not.    For the businesses, this makes it possible to continue their activities during the period of quarantine measures, as well as minimizes the risks of the spread of Covid-19 and reduces the number of contacts leading to infection.    The use of the application for both entrepreneurs and citizens is free.    Today, every person who becomes ill with COVID-19 in any form (symptomatic or asymptomatic) undertakes to comply with the home quarantine regime and assures them with a personal signature on the receipt. However, we often come across facts of violation of the self-isolation regime."    Archived web link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211105195803/https://egov.kz/cms/en/articles/prilozhenie-ashyq

Vaccines: Sputnik V, QazVac, CoronaVac and Sinopharm.    Quote: "Has the government of Kazakhstan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes  Are vaccines available in Kazakhstan for U.S. citizens to receive?  Yes, for permanent residents (see below).  Which vaccines are available in Kazakhstan? Sputnik V, QazVac, CoronaVac and Sinopharm.  On April 7, 2021, the Minister of Health announced in a press briefing that foreigners who live and work in Kazakhstan and have permanent residence cards may receive COVID-19 vaccination free of charge just like Kazakhstani citizens.  Currently, the only record of this announcement is in media reporting.  The Ministry of Health of Kazakhstan initiated a multi-stage vaccination program on February 1, 2021"  Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20211123093223/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Confirmation form covidpass.lv must be completed. The Covid-19 test is not required; exception - when returning from very high-risk countries. Self-isolation is not required, exception - when returning from very high-risk countries.  From 24 December 2021 to 11 January 2022, persons who have performed an RNA test within 72 hours prior to entry or antigen test within 48 hours prior to entry and the test is negative may enter Latvia from Germany, the United Kingdom, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Belgium, Ireland and Russia. Persons who are unable to present a negative test to the passenger carrier shall not be admitted to the vehicle.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106093917/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Everyone will have to show their health pass to drink inside and on the terraces of restaurants and bars. This also applies to young people aged 16 to 18   The health pass will also be required for access to theatres and congresses when there are more than 300 people.  Booking is required in restaurants and there is maximum of 12 people per table (seated service)  There must be a distance between tables in restaurants of at least 1 metre on the terrace and inside  For customers, wearing a mask will be required in the queue. However, it will no longer be compulsory inside the establishment  Standing consumption is not allowed  In sports halls, auditoriums or congress halls, the public capacity is increased from 70% to 100% of the seats, an exemption being possible on presentation of a specific health protocol  http://web.archive.org/web/20211221134119/https://covid19.mc/en/the-sanitary-measures-in-force/

No change policy.   In Chisinau, 20 educational institutions operate in a mixed system and more than 1,700 pupils study online.  At the same time, 20 municipal institutions continue to operate in a mixed regime and 1,700 pupils continue to study online. The measure is due to the large number of students in the class, which makes it impossible to be physically present in the classroom without violating anti-coronavirus prevention measures. No policy changes.  Domestic Restrictions. Authorities have extended the nationwide state of public health emergency (SoE) until at least Jan. 15 due to rising COVID-19 cases; the SoE was previously slated to expire Nov. 30. As part of their attempts to curb the recent surge in infections, officials will continue to enforce restrictions on the use of certain facilities and on indoor and outdoor mass events.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20211221145827/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/551411/moldova-authorities-tighten-covid-19-related-international-entry-restrictions-for-travelers-from-eight-african-nations-as-of-nov-30-update-24

The National Public Health Emergency Commission in Moldova extended the National State of Public Health Emergency. Announcements from the Commission and restrictions under the ongoing State of Public Health Emergency are available on the Government of Moldova website.  Face-masks are mandatory in all public indoor spaces.    Chisinau has a mask mandate for open-air public events, as well as social-distancing rules.  Additional restrictions could be lifted or (re)imposed with little notice.  Moldovan authorities established new public health measures to limit the spread of COVID-19 infection at all public events and gatherings, both indoor and outdoor.  Anyone over the age of 18 eating in a restaurant or cafÃ© or attending any show, concert, festival, theater, cinema, concert hall, nightclub, dance floor, etc., must present one of the following documents: 1) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 2) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date.   Source: https://archive.ph/WIEbZ (Last updated: January 08, 2022).

There are no special restrictions on gatherings. General recommendations are available. Effective November 28, 2021, Moldova banned entry to foreigners who were physically present in the last 14 days in South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Namibia, Eswatini, or Malawi. Source: https://archive.ph/WIEbZ (Last updated: January 08, 2022).

No changes in policy.  Key Policy Responses as of July 1, 2021. A comprehensive fiscal package has been adopted as per two 2020 State Budget Amendments, following several targeted fiscal measures to support businesses and vulnerable households, such as expanding unemployment benefits and strengthening existing targeted social assistance, tax relief for sectors affected by state-imposed restrictions, delaying tax payment deadlines to mid-2020, suspending tax audits and other controls, and increasing state budget allocations to the budget emergency and health funds and to a mortgage guarantee program. The approved 2021 Budget envisages more support to the health sector, and farmers support.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20211221154516/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No changes.  Negotiations between the IMF mission and the Moldovan Government have successfully ended with a stafflevel agreement for Moldova to access 564 M USD. The programme will be implemented in a time span of 40 months and is subject to the implementation of several prior actions, including on central bank independence, the correction of past policy slippages, and the adoption of credible fiscal plans. Also, Moldova will use the Special Drawing Rights of the International Monetary Fund IMF), to finance the state budgetâs needs, with about US$236 million to be allocated to finance the necessities of Moldovaâs state budget.  Source: https://archive.ph/gR5ei

People will now be able to get the vaccine booster 3 months, instead of 6 months, after their last vaccination or most recent positive test. A total of 8.5 million adults are eligible for a booster. Before the end of 2021 nearly all people over 60 will have been invited to get their booster vaccination."  https://archive.fo/z3iwp

"The booster vaccination can be scheduled from 3 months after the last COVID-19 vaccination or from 3 months after recovery from COVID-19. "  http://web.archive.org/web/20211231110223/https://www.rivm.nl/en/news/people-born-in-1987-and-1988-invited-for-covid-19-booster-vaccination

"Events  Limit the number of social gatherings and events you attend.    See questions about events and private gatherings for rules and advice. Some of the main points:    Rules for indoor and outdoor events:    No alcohol may be served. The organiser must ensure that all guests can keep a distance of at least 1-metre from other people than those within their household or corresponding close relations, among other rules.    Private events/gatherings at a public venue or in a rented/borrowed venue:    Indoors: a maximum of 20 people â a maximum of 50 people at memorial services.    Outdoors: a maximum of 50 people.    Requirement to wear a face covering.     Indoor public events:    Without designated seating: a maximum of 20 people.    With designated seating: a maximum of 50 people.    Requirement to wear a face covering.    Outdoor public events:    Without designated seating: a maximum of 100 people.    With designated seating: 200 people x 3.    Recommendation to wear a face covering."    https://archive.fo/khv0S

"The special entry restrictions that were introduced for travellers arriving from 8 countries in Southern Africa at the end of November will be removed. The measures were introduced to limit and delay the spread of the Omicron variant. The Norwegian Government is keeping the strict general entry restrictions that apply to arrival in Norway.  âOmicron is now established in many countries, including Norway. The Norwegian Directorate of Health and the Norwegian Institute of Public Health believe that it is no longer expedient to keep specific measures that target travellers from these 8 countries. This is why the special measures are being removed. We are also keeping the strict general entry restrictions that apply to arrival in Norway,â says Minister of Health and Care Services Ingvild Kjerkol.  The special measures targeted travellers arriving from South Africa, Mozambique, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Botswana, Lesotho, Eswatini, and Malawi, where the virus variant was discovered. The change will enter into effect on 22 December at 12 am."    "Measures that will be kept  The strict general entry measures that apply to arrival in Norway will be kept. They include:  a requirement of entry registration for all travellers;    a general requirement for all travellers to get tested upon arrival in Norway;    a requirement of documentation of a negative test taken before arrival for people who cannot produce a verifiable COVID-19 certificate showing that they are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 during the past 6 months;    travel quarantine for people who arrive from a country that triggers a duty to quarantine and who cannot produce a verifiable COVID-19 certificate showing that they are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 during the past 6 months."  https://archive.fo/upo3s#selection-1393.1-1427.243

"A requirement to wear a face covering when it is not possible to keep a distance of at least 1 metre in shops, shopping centres, venues that serve food or alcohol, public transport, taxis, and indoor station areas. The requirement also applies to employees unless physical barriers have been put in place.  The requirement to wear a face covering also applies to hairdressers, skin care professionals, and other businesses with one-to-one contact.  The requirement to wear a face covering also applies to indoor events, libraries, and museums. (new)  The requirement to wear a face covering does not apply when sitting at a table in a venue that serves food or alcohol (currently in force) or when eating or drinking while seated. (new)  There is already a national recommendation in place to wear a face covering in places where there are many people and it is difficult to keep a distance â for example at the cloakroom after attending an event or when you are in a crowd leaving a football stadium."    https://web.archive.org/web/20211217163543/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/stricter-national-measures-to-limit-the-spread-of-omicron/id2892042/

"Public transport/taxis  Recommendation to avoid using public transport to travel to events. Requirement to wear a face covering when it is not possible to keep a 1-metre distance. In taxis, a requirement for both the passenger and the driver to wear a face covering.    Shops/shopping centres  Requirement to wear a face covering when it is not possible to keep a 1-metre distance."    https://archive.fo/khv0S

From 20 December 2021 to 9 January 2022, all primary and secondary school students will switch to remote learning. Nurseries and kindergartens will operate without any change.    Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  From 1.11, the obligation to cover the mouth and nose will be introduced in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.    https://archive.fo/J3kN7

29/12/21    Education  All students returned to full-time teaching.    Find out more about school rules.    Important!  From December 20, 2021 to January 9, 2022, learning in schools will be conducted remotely.    Nurseries and kindergartens  Nurseries and kindergartens are open and provide care for children.    https://archive.fo/qdnvf

5/1/22    Education  All students returned to full-time teaching.    Find out more about school rules.    Important!  From December 20, 2021 to January 9, 2022, learning in schools will be conducted remotely.    https://archive.fo/XrJXE
14/1/22  Students returned to school    Education  All students returned to full-time teaching.    Find out more about school rules.    https://archive.fo/1xqaS

Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  From 1.11, the obligation to cover the mouth and nose will be introduced in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     https://archive.fo/WY5IJ

culture and entertainment  Museums and art galleries  They function in a strict sanitary regime. There is a limit of people - 1 person. for 15 m 2 .    Attention! The number of persons vaccinated against COVID-19 is not counted if they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Cinemas  They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. It is necessary to cover the mouth and nose.    It is not allowed to eat or drink in the cinemas.    Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Theaters, operas, philharmonics  Outdoor:    They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. Maintain a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners.    Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    In rooms:    They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. Maintain a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners. Ensuring that no more than 1 person per 15 m2 of the area is present in the room at the same time. It is necessary to cover the mouth and nose    Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Houses and centers of culture  Conducting activities by cultural centers and centers as well as community centers is allowed in the open air and indoors, provided that the participation does not exceed 30%. participants. Ensure that participants follow the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Concerts and circus performances  Events may take place under the following conditions:    making available to viewers or listeners no more than 30 percent. number of seats,  keep a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners in the absence of designated seats in the audience and ensure that no more than 1 person per 15 square meters is present in the room at the same time,  ensure that viewers or listeners comply with the order to cover their mouth and nose.  Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Concerts and circus performances may be organized outdoors under the following conditions:    making available to viewers or listeners no more than 30 percent. number of seats,  keep a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners in the absence of designated seats in the audience,  ensure that viewers or listeners comply with the order to cover their mouth and nose.  Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Outdoor amusement parks  Theme parks may operate at up to 30%. occupancy.    Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Libraries  Possibility to make collections available, provided that no more than 1 person per 15 mÂ² is present in the library, with the exception of librarians. Before entering the library, information about the limit of people should be posted.         Conducting activities by public and scientific libraries consisting in the organization of meetings and events is allowed indoors, provided that:    while maintaining a distance of 1.5 m between participants;  that participants comply with the obligation to cover their mouth and nose.       Attention! The number of persons vaccinated against COVID-19 is not counted if they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services. 14/1/22  Restrictions on capacity limits for those not vaccinated    CULTURAL EVENTS - RESTRICTIONS    Museums and art galleries    Museums and art galleries are open and can operate under a strict sanitary regime. A limit of 1 person per 15 m2 is in effect.         The limit does not include people vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they present:    the EU Digital Covid Certificate;  or a vaccination certificate, a positive test result and a recovery certificate.  Failure to show these documents may result in denial of service.         Cinemas    Cinemas have resumed both outdoor and indoor activities. They operate under a strict sanitary regime at no more than 30% occupancy. Wearing masks covering both mouth and nose is mandatory.         The limit does not include people vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they present:    the EU Digital Covid Certificate;  or a vaccination certificate, a positive test result and a recovery certificate.  Failure to show these documents may result in denial of service.         Theatres, operas, and philharmonics    Outdoors:    Theaters, operas and philharmonic halls have resumed their activities in the open air. They operate under a strict sanitary regime at no more than 30% occupancy.         The limit does not include people vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they present:    the EU Digital Covid Certificate;  or a vaccination certificate, a positive test result and a recovery certificate.  Failure to show these documents may result in denial of service.         Indoors:    Theaters, operas and philharmonic halls have resumed their indoor activity. They operate under a strict sanitary regime at no more than 30% occupancy. Event organisers must ensure that the limit of 1 person per 15 m2 is observed. Wearing masks covering both mouth and nose is mandatory.         The limit does not include people vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they present:    the EU Digital Covid Certificate;  or a vaccination certificate, a positive test result and a recovery certificate.  Failure to show these documents may result in denial of service.         Cultural and community centres    Cultural and community centres may conduct activities both outdoors and indoors, provided that the number of attendees does not exceed 15 people and a distance of 1.5 m between them is maintained, and that participants comply with the requirement to cover mouth and nose.         The limit does not include people vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they present:    the EU Digital Covid Certificate;  or a vaccination certificate, a positive test result and a recovery certificate.  Failure to show these documents may result in denial of service.         Concerts and circus shows    Indoor concert activities have been resumed under the following conditions:    no more than 30% of seats may be made available to viewers or listeners,  a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners must be maintained, and if no designated seats are available, a limit of 1 person per 10 metres squared must be observed,  ensuring that viewers or listeners comply with the requirement to cover mouth and nose.  Concerts and circus performances can be organised outdoors under the following conditions:    no more than 30% of seats may be made available to viewers or listeners,  a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners must be maintained, and if no designated seats are available, a limit of 1 person per 15 metres squared must be observed. Persons vaccinated against Covid-19 shall not count towards the limit.  ensuring that viewers or listeners comply with the requirement to cover mouth and nose.       The limit does not include people vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they present:    the EU Digital Covid Certificate;  or a vaccination certificate, a positive test result and a recovery certificate.  Failure to show these documents may result in denial of service.         Entertainment â Outdoor amusement parks    Outdoor amusement parks can resume operations at up to 30% occupancy.         The limit does not include people vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they present:    the EU Digital Covid Certificate;  or a vaccination certificate, a positive test result and a recovery certificate.  Failure to show these documents may result in denial of service.         Libraries    Libraries may make their collections available to readers provided that the limit of 1 person per 15 m2 of space is observed; librarians shall not count towards this limit. Information on the limit of persons allowed into the library shall be posted at the libraryâs entrance.    Public and research libraries may organise indoor meetings and events provided that the following criteria are met:    no more than 15 attendees are allowed, with each of them maintaining a distance of 1.5 m from other persons;  ensuring that attendees comply with the requirement to cover mouth and nose.  PUBLIC TRANSPORT  Public transport vehicles may be boarded by a limited number of persons.    All means of public transport across Poland may only make up to 100% of seats available to passengers.         RELIGIOUS CEREMONIES    We also recommend that all ceremonies be held outdoors.Tthere is a limit in places of religious worship - a max. 30% of full capacity.    Important! In churches and places of worship it is mandatory to cover your mouth and nose.    The limit does not include people vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they present:    the EU Digital Covid Certificate;  or a vaccination certificate, a positive test result and a recovery certificate.  Failure to show these documents may result in denial of service.    GATHERINGS AND MEETINGS  GATHERINGS    Up to 100 people may participate in a public gathering at the same time. Participants are required to maintain a distance of 1.5 m from others. Additionally, the distance between individual gatherings must be at least 100 m.    MEETINGS    Up to 100 people may participate in events and meetings, either outdoors, indoors or in designated gastronomic areas. A distance between individual tables must be maintained (only every other table may be occupied, with a 1.5 m distance between tables â unless there is a screen between them with a height of at least 1 m, counting from the tableâs surface).    This number does not include persons vaccinated against COVID-19.         WEDDINGS, COMMUNIONS, FUNERAL RECEPTIONS AND OTHER CELEBRATIONS  Special events may be organised outdoors and indoors alike (e.g. inside restaurants). A limit of 150 attendees is in effect. Such events may only take place under a strict sanitary regime. A distance between individual tables must be maintained (only every other table may be occupied, with a 1.5 m distance between tables â unless there is a screen between them with a height of at least 1 m, counting from the tableâs surface).    This number does not include persons vaccinated against COVID-19.         NIGHT CLUBS, DISCOS AND OTHER PLACES FOR DANCING  Night clubs, discos and other dancing venues are closed. They will be allowed to operate exclusively on New Year's Eve (31/12-1/01) under sanitary regime (max. 100 people, COVID-19 certificate holders not included).    The limit does not include people vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they present:    the EU Digital Covid Certificate;  or a vaccination certificate, a positive test result and a recovery certificate.  Failure to show these documents may result in denial of service.         FAIRS, EXHIBITIONS, CONGRESSES AND CONFERENCES  Trade fairs, congresses and conferences can be organised provided that the limit of 1 person per 15 m2 is complied with.     https://archive.fo/xHGfE

Public transport  Throughout the country, public transport can transport no more than 100% of passengers at the same time. occupancy. Remember to cover your face with a mask.    Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  From 1.11, the obligation to cover the mouth and nose will be introduced in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     https://archive.fo/WY5IJ

International borders and movement  Check the website of the Border Guard  for the rules of entry and stay in the territory of the Republic of Poland.    Important! From November 30 to January 10, flights are banned from Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe.    People returning from these countries cannot be released from quarantine for 14 days.    The provisions on quarantine do not apply to people who have:    EU digital COVID certification for COVID-19 vaccination, COVID-19 infection or negative COVID-19 test;  certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery due to COVID-19 recognized as equivalent to the EU COVID Certificate.  Attention! From December 15, people arriving from outside the Schengen area must have a COVID 19 test performed within 24 hours prior to crossing the border, starting from the test result.    Vaccination does not release you from the obligation to perform the test. From December 18, the test does not need to be carried out by children under the age of 5.    It is also possible to perform a test at some airports in Poland, before the border check. We encourage you to verify the information on the websites of individual airports. From 18 December, the test can be performed at the airport within 3 hours of crossing the border.    Remember! People traveling from outside the European Union, from outside the Schengen area and from outside Turkey cannot be released from quarantine on the basis of a test performed within 48 hours after returning to Poland. This possibility is allowed only after 8 days. The obligation to undergo quarantine is deemed to be fulfilled when the negative test result is entered by the medical diagnostic laboratory into the ICT system.    Important!  Persons who, after arrival, stay in the territory of the Republic of Poland for no longer than 24 hours and have a flight ticket confirming departure from the territory of the Republic of Poland within 24 hours, are exempt from the obligation to undergo quarantine.    From July 17, a person crossing the state border of the Republic of Poland by plane - before checking in - must fill in the traveler location card.    More details in the For travelers tab  !    International rail traffic  The movement of passengers in rail transport, with the crossing of the Polish border with the Republic of Belarus, is suspended.    Valid until December 31st    https://archive.fo/gBEb5

No new policies. Continued policy is an increase to income for the âtax-free allowanceâ for low-wage earners. Can a test referral only be issued by a GP? Can a doctor from night and holiday telephoto issue such a referral?  An order for a coronavirus test can be issued by a doctor on duty as part of night or holiday health care.    You can also sign up for an online test. All you have to do is fill in the form available at gov.pl/dom . You will be asked to answer a few questions. Based on the data you provide, the system will determine if you qualify for the test.    How it's working?    Go to gov.pl/dom and click the "Form" button.  Answer the survey questions.  If the system qualifies you for the test, a consultant from the Home Medical Care Monitoring Center will contact you.  You will receive an order for the test from the eKolejka system.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

I was in close contact with a person who tested positive. Should I report it somewhere?  If you are in close contact with a person infected with the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus (this person has obtained a confirmed, positive PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infection), report this fact to the sanitary inspection. Use the online form: Application for quarantine or isolation by the Sanepid.    If you have questions about quarantine, please call the hotline to contact the sanitary inspection : +48 22 25 00 115. The  hotline is open 24 hours a day.    Important! If you know you have been in close contact with an infected or sick person, stay home - even if you have not yet decided to quarantine, and you are feeling well. Avoid contact with other people. You can infect them if you find out that you are infected. If this is not possible, use all required personal protective equipment.    Attention! If you have been vaccinated for COVID-19, you will not be placed in quarantine. The rule applies from December 28, 2020.    However, from December 15, family  members of people suffering from COVID19 must undergo a coronavirus test, regardless of the certificate they have.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

RESTRICTIONS CONCERNING MOVEMENT    1.5 METER â MINIMUM DISTANCE BETWEEN PEDESTRIANS  It is mandatory that a distance of least 1.5 meters be maintained between pedestrians.    The following persons are exempt from the restriction:    parents with children who require care (younger than 13),  persons who live in one household or run a household together,  disabled persons, persons incapable of moving on their own, persons with a special educational needs statement and their carers.  COVERING YOUR MOUTH AND NOSE ONLY WITH A MASK IN PUBLIC SPACES    It is mandatory to cover your mouth and nose in such places as:    in buses, trams and trains,  in shops, malls, banks, markets and post offices  in cinemas and theatres,  at physicianâs offices, in outpatient clinics and hospitals, in massage and tattoo parlours  in churches, at schools and universities,  In government offices (when going there to take care of certain matters) and other civic centres.  Where is it not mandatory to cover your mouth and nose? In forests, parks, green squares, botanical gardens, historic gardens, family community gardens and on beaches as well as while travelling by private car.    Important!  Exemption from the obligation to cover the mouth and nose is limited only to persons who have a medical certificate or a document confirming:    a pervasive developmental disorder,  a mental disorder,  moderate, severe or profound intellectual disability,  difficulties in uncovering the mouth or nose on their own.  Covering the mouth and nose in public spaces is obligatory throughout the entire country.    Important! You may only use a mask to cover your mouth and nose. Scarves or face shields are not allowed because they do not fulfil their main function, which is to provide protection against the virus!      https://archive.fo/wS5eU

Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  From 1.11, the obligation to cover the mouth and nose will be introduced in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     https://archive.fo/WY5IJ

On November 30 the Government of Romania issued a measure barring entry of non EU citizens traveling from these African countries (Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe.) due to concerns about the COVID Omicron variant.  This measure will be in effect until February 6, 2022, and may be extended.  All passengers arriving in Romania are required to complete a digital Passenger Locator Form at least 24 hours before arriving in the country. It can also be completed at the point of entry.  Foreign citizens may enter Romania without a negative COVID-19 test, but are subject to quarantine requirements if a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test is not presented, regardless of vaccination status.    Beginning January 9, 2022, foreign citizens arriving in Romania from third countries (countries that are not member of the European Union, the European Economic Area or the Swiss Confederation) must quarantine for 5 days if they are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 within 180 days of travel, or 10 days if they are unvaccinated or have not recently recovered from COVID-19. The exceptions from quarantine requirements include fully vaccinated or recently recovered travelers who present a negative RT-PCR test taken no more than 48 hours prior to boarding, children aged 12 or under, and children aged 12 â 16 who present a negative RT-PCR test taken no more than 48 hours prior to boarding.   http://web.archive.org/web/20220116204506/https://ro.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From October 25 to February 25, enterprises in the capital must switch to remote work:  - at least 30 percent of the total number of employees;  - all employees over 60 years of age and suffering from chronic diseases. The only exception is for employees whose presence in the workplace is critical to the functioning of the organization.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211031173008/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

Businesses in the capital must switch to remote work for:  - at least 30 percent of the total number of employees;  - all employees over 60 years of age and suffering from chronic diseases.   There are exceptions, including for employees whose presence in the workplace is critical to the functioning of the organization., those who have been vaccinated against COVID-19 and to workers who have been ill, as well as to employees of medical organizations, defense industry enterprises, Rosatom, Roskosmos and some other strategic industries.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220113211851/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/
In Moscow, events over 500 people require masks and proof of vaccination.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220113211851/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

From November 8, the mandatory use of QR codes and masks is introduced at concert, entertainment, cultural, entertainment, sports and other events with the simultaneous presence of more than 500 people. Organizers of events with fewer than 500 participants are encouraged to make similar decisions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220102180611/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

In Moscow, events over 500 people require masks and proof of vaccination; events under 500 people are recommended to conduct the same measures.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220113211851/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/
No policy change  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106161856/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Public transport is open, with masks and social distancing required.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220113212612/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

People above 60 in Moscow must stay at home or in their country house. They can go out only in these cases: when they need to go to the store, walk their pets, take out the trash, go to work, to the clinic or hospital, take a walk or play sports in the fresh air. They may also leave the house if there is a direct threat to life and health. These measures do not apply to those who have had COVID-19, as well as those who have been vaccinated against coronavirus.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220113211851/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

Some regions require proof of vaccination for internal flights from different regions. Health passes are also required on intercity trains.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220113213253/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2022/01/13/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-jan-13-a69117

Entry into Russia is not allowed for any passengers arriving from, or having visited during the last fourteen days, Botswana, Eswatini, Hong Kong, Lesotho, Madagascar, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Tanzania and Zimbabwe. All other foreign passengers arriving in Russia should have a negative PCR test certificate in Russian or English. Anyone testing positive for COVID in Russia is required to quarantine, though the length of this is determined by local jurisdictions   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220113220751/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/russia/entry-requirements

Curfew was introduced on 11/25/2021, all residents are required to stay at home from 5 am until 1 am the next day. Exemptions from curfew are visiting a doctor; travelling to get vaccinated or a Covid-19 test (between 5:00 and 20:00); the essential shopping and services - opening hours limited between 5:00 and 20:00; commuting to and from work (with home office recommended), employees will need confirmation from their employer; travel to and from school and kindergarten (between 5:00 and 20:00); care for family members or other relatives; walking pets within 500m from your home, caring for farm animals; being in nature within the district you live; attending funerals, wedding ceremonies and christenings (between 5:00 and 20:00);  travel abroad and to mass events.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206182423/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22790201/slovakia-enters-all-out-lockdown.html?ref=njctse  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206180117/https://korona.gov.sk/nudzovy-stav-a-zakaz-vychadzania-od-25-novembra-2021/

A national curfew from 20.00 to 05.00 the next day is in place, with people required to stay at home during this time expect for a restricted list of essential purposes.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229123630/https://korona.gov.sk/nudzovy-stav-a-zakaz-vychadzania-od-25-novembra-2021/

Stay at home requirement imposed, but no explicit restrictions on internal movement.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206180117/https://korona.gov.sk/nudzovy-stav-a-zakaz-vychadzania-od-25-novembra-2021/

Whilst curfew rules are in place, interval movement outside of these times is not recommended to stop or is prohibited. From 10 December, travelling on some long-distance buses and trains has required proof of vaccination, recovery or testing to use.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229120510/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovakia/coronavirus  Source

Persons who have visited the Republic of South Africa, Botswana, Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Israel, Hong Kong or the Seychelles in the last 14 days and who enter the territory of the Slovak Republic from 1 December 2021 must enter quarantine, which will end in asymptomatic completion of its isolation on day 14 or by receiving two negative results from RT-PCR tests for COVID-19, whereby laboratory diagnosis of COVID-19 can be made first on the first day of isolation and then on the eighth day of isolation. In children under the age of twelve and two months of age, with an asymptomatic course of isolation, this ends with the termination of the obligation of home isolation for persons living in the same household.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213105530/https://korona.gov.sk/cestovanie-do-sr/
No policy change.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229120510/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovakia/coronavirus

About 80% of the lost income can be claimed back through the scheme, a maximum of 1100 euros (approx. 935 pounds) a month. Employers need to guarantee workers keep their job at least two months after receiving income support.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206192447/https://www.pomahameludom.sk/
No policy change.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229121010/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No change in policy. Tests are free for those who are symptomatic or if a test has been recommended by a medical practitioner. While the tracing infrastructure was greatly expanded during the pandemic, the chief public health official admitted in the summer that they have only limited capacity to trace all contacts.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211206194252/https://www.topky.sk/cl/10/2175429/KORONAVIRUS-Mikas-avizuje-novinky-v-trasovani-kontaktov--V-terene-moze-zasiahnut-oproti-minulej-vlne-viac-ludi-

Contact tracing services are limited. People who test positive are asked to tell their doctor and anyone they have been in close contact with in the 2 days before symptom onset.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229121805/https://korona.gov.sk/en/

Masks are required everywhere outside the home if another person is closer than 2 meters and few other exceptions (ex. children, weddings).  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206195134/https://korona.gov.sk/povinnost-nosit-ruska-a-respiratory/

A standard face mask is required in all outdoor events, and when less than 2 metres away from people outside of your household outdoors. FFP2-standard face masks are required at all indoor venues and areas.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229120510/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovakia/coronavirus

Foreigners who are in the country as residents, under protected status, or international status are required to provide a Hayat Eve?Sigar?(HES) code for inner city public transportation, inter-city bus travel rest stops, hotel reservations, and international and domestic flights. Starting September 6, intercity travel by bus, plane, train or other public transportation will require proof of vaccination or a negative PCR test taken within the past 48 hours. This requirement applies to individuals 18 years old and older including foreign nationals with Turkish residency. Travel using a private vehicle will not require proof of vaccination or a negative PCR test. Individuals who fail to provide the necessary documentation will not be permitted to board public transportation. Starting December 6, 2021, all air travelers aged two and above, regardless of vaccination status or nationality, must show a negative COVID-19 test. Your negative test result must be from a COVID-19 viral test performed one calendar day before the day of your flight to the U.S. In other words, the testing window can be slightly more than 24 hours before your departure.  If an individual on a particular aircraft/vehicle/vessel is found to have COVID-19, the information forms completed upon arrival will be used to identify others have been in contact with them;   those individuals will then be subject to 14-day isolation/quarantine.???   https://archive.vn/6vG9g
